Steve Bannon, a media executive and a former senior advisor to Donald Trump, has considered a campaign in the 2028 United States presidential election.
Background
Steve Bannon served as the chief executive of Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. After Trump's first inauguration, Bannon served as senior counselor and the White House chief strategist until August 2017. Bannon served four months in prison on contempt of Congress charges; if Bannon were to be elected president, he would be the first president to have served time in prison and the second to be convicted of a crime, after Trump.
Pre-candidacy developments
At the 2025 Conservative Political Action Conference in February, Bannon's supporters encouraged attendees to vote for him in a straw poll. According to The New York Times in March, supporters of Bannon were "quick to mention him as a potential candidate for president in 2028". That month, Politico reported that Bannon had privately discussed a campaign in the 2028 United States presidential election. He continued to express support for Donald Trump, telling NewsNation's Chris Cuomo that he expected Trump to run for a third, unconstitutional term and that he would win.
On August 7, the Daily Mail reported that Bannon was considering a presidential campaign.
Polling
In a straw poll conducted at the 2025 Conservative Political Action Conference, Bannon received twelve percent of votes, behind vice president JD Vance.
